subject: on vs. ah
msgSnippet: My main problem, however, is that there seems to be no easily-definable rule as to which character to use under which circumstances.  Shouldn t there be a
messageBody:
My main problem, however, is that there seems to be no
easily-definable rule as to which character to use under which
circumstances. Shouldn't there be a convention as to which is used or
not used if no differences are perceived? Should it be 32 or 34 for
QS?

Perhaps if a British person could explain to me, in fairly
straightforward terms, how they know which sound goes where when they
see it written, it will click for me. Or is it simply a matter of
memorization?

Are there any American English speakers who hear these differences and
can illuminate me?

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Hugh Birkenhead" <mixsynth@f...
> wrote:
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "kyudosha" <kyudosha@y...>
>
>
> > The a-vowel in "cAlm" and "whAt" both use the same letter and
sound
> > quite similar in British English as near as I can tell, so why not
> > combine them as T.O. did?
>
> While I'm not a normal peruser of this group, you're probably not a
normal
> peruser of the "shavian" yahoogroup that runs in parallel with this
one. If
> you look at the topics recently running there, you'll see that this
"on
> versus ah" issue (as we refer to it there) has been debated for
months, if
> not years.
>
> It is true that many American English speakers do not make a
distinction
> between the two in their speech. But most major dictionaries there
list a
> difference in their pronunciation guides so it's not hard to look up
where
> differences occur. But for those people who just don't see it, in
practical
> terms, the rule we agreed upon in the Shavian group was to use the
'on'
> letter ('ox' in QS) for any word where that sound is heard, and
simply
> memorise the few words that use 'ah' (e.g. father, lather, calm,
palm,
> etc.).
>
> I developed a 'subset' of Shavian that did away with the "on/ah"
difference
> amongst other alterations, purely as an experiment to see if it
would be a
> viable 'easier' alternative. It was much closer to QS in many ways
but used
> Shavian letterforms. It's never been seriously tested by anyone but
myself.
> I'll try to find a table of characters and post it.
>
> Hugh B

My main problem, however, is that there seems to be no 
easily-definable rule as to which character to use under which 
circumstances.  Shouldn't there be a convention as to which is used or 
not used if no differences are perceived?  Should it be 32 or 34 for 
QS?

Perhaps if a British person could explain to me, in fairly 
straightforward terms, how they know which sound goes where when they 
see it written, it will click for me.  Or is it simply a matter of 
memorization?

Are there any American English speakers who hear these differences and 
can illuminate me?
